abstracts.cdata!:
The Power Sector Efficiency
            Project's overall outcome is assessed as satisfactory
            given that most of the objectives were achieved, albeit
            after delays and subject to occasional shortfalls during the
            implementation. Some key lessons include: 1) The Performance
            Agreement signed as a condition of effectiveness, and which
            was designed as an instrument to enhance Nepal Electricity
            Authority's (NEA) autonomy and monitor its
            institutional performance, has proven to be difficult to
            enforce. 2) Effective training and recruitment of qualified
            staff should have been given more priority to ensure
            institutional development actions are sustainable. 3)
            Setting specific performance targets and having to rely on
            other donors funding for implementation creates risks,
            particularly in a situation where strong corporate
            management is not yet in place. 4) Key issues and
            procurement must be addressed early in the project cycle. 5)
            Appropriate external audit arrangements can be used as a
            tool for increasing accountability and institution building.
            6) Environmental impact assessments should be initiated
            early in the project cycle. 7) Public consultations should
            be made an integral part of the preparatory process to
            create a political consensus on proposed hydropower investments.
